awd_titl_txt: Functional Analyses of the Neural Circuits Underlying Vocal Production in Xenopus Laevis
awd_abstract_narration:
The most salient output of brain function is behavior.  However, how the nervous system produces behavior is not well understood, largely because most of the neural pathways underlying behavior are complicated.  In this research project, vocal behavior of African clawed frogs is used as a model because their vocal neural pathways are simple and straight forward, and the pathways in action can be studied using techniques that were previously developed in the PI's laboratory.  In addition to their simplicity and accessibility, the frog vocal pathways provide a unique opportunity to study how female and male brains function differently; male and female frogs produce sex-specific vocalizations during the breeding season, and the injection of male-specific hormones into an adult female results in male-like vocalizations within thirteen weeks.  In this study, the focus is placed on one group of cells that are known to play a critical role in the operation of the pathways.  A variety of experimental techniques will be used to understand where these neurons are, how these neurons function, and how they respond to male-specific hormones.  The results of the study will not only provide us with the understanding of how behaviors are generated in the two sexes, but also provide us with an insight into how human brains generates rhythmic activity such as alpha and gamma waves, many of which are known to underlie cognitive processes, and known to be disrupted in diseased states.  

A fundamentally important question in neuroscience is how neural networks function to generate motor programs that underlie behavior.  Although analyses of a complete neural network that generates behavior is a formidable task, the relative simplicity of the Xenopus vocal network combined with the development of the fictive preparation (a "singing brain in a dish" preparation) and the application of behavioral, electrophysiological, anatomical, and newly developed optogenetic techniques allows detailed investigation of the dynamic organization of brain in action.  The results of the proposed study will not only provide insight into the structure, function, and plasticity of the rhythm-generating neural network at the cellular levels, but also allow us to understand the logic of how a feedback loop should be engineered into a network to generate stable rhythms.  Rhythmic neuronal activity is not limited to motor systems, but is prevalent across the entire CNS and is considered to underlie important functions such as perception and cognition.  Thus, understanding the biophysical principles that govern rhythm generation using a simple neural network has a potential to elucidate mechanisms underlying neuronal oscillations in general.  On a technical level, successful application of optogenetic tools to the Xenopus fictive preparation in vitro fills an important gap between research efforts conducted on genetic vs non-genetic model organisms.  There are many non-genetic model organisms that present unique questions.  The ability to express genetically encoded tools in non-model organisms represents a revolutionary change in the field of comparative neuroscience.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamentally important question in neuroscience is how neural networks function to generate motor programs that underlie behavior.  Although analyses of a complete neural network that generates behavior is a formidable task, we used the calling behavior of African clawed frog as a model to understand how neurons function to generate behavior.

In African clawed frogs the vocalizations are produced by the neural networks known as central pattern generators (CPGs) in the brainstem that produce rhythmic outputs in the absence of rhythmic sensory of descending inputs.  In this project, we examined the organization, function, and plasticity of the vocal pathways.  Preliminary results from the Yamaguchi lab demonstrate that the CPG relies critically on an ascending feedback loop (from the motor to premotor centers) for its function.  Here, we addressed how the vocal CPG generates motor programs, focusing on the “feedback” neurons that carry motor signal (efference copy) back to the premotor nucleus. 

 

First, we discovered that the feedback loop is necessary for only one component of the male vocalizations.  Advertisement calls of male African clawed frogs are made of fast and slow trills that contain clicks repeated at fast (60Hz) and slow (30Hz) rates.

Transection of feedback pathways only disrupts fast, but not slow trills.  At a cellular level, disruption of cholinergic synaptic transmission within the vocal motor nucleus resulted in abnormal firing patterns of neurons in the premotor nucleus, suggesting that the inputs from the feedback neurons within the motor nucleus to the premotor nucleus mediated by cholinergic synaptic transmission plays an important role in shaping the vocal rhythms during fast trill generation. 

 

Second, we discovered that the vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) can be used as an efficient vector to transfect neurons of African clawed frogs.  Injection of engineered VSV resulted in high expression of the reporter genes by the neurons of adult clawed frogs.  Successful application of viral vector tools to the clawed frog brains is not only a major technical breakthrough for my research program but also fills an important gap between research efforts conducted on genetic vs non-genetic model organisms.  Although there is no doubt that research on genetic model organisms has provided a wealth of information in every aspect of life sciences, there are many other non-genetic model organisms that present unique questions.  The ability to express genetically encoded tools in non-model organisms is likely to be viewed as revolutionary change by the field of comparative neuroscience.  

 

Third, we analyzed the molecular profile of the vocal neurons in the premotor nucleus of the central vocal pathways.  Using immunohistochemical techniques and constellation pharmacology, we discovered that one of the vocal neurons named Fast Trill Neurons (FTNs) can be categorized into four groups with unique expression patterns of NMDA receptors, GABAA receptors, acetylcholine receptors, and substance P receptors.  The application of substance P and acetylcholine directly depolarizes the membrane potentials of FTNs and the application of their agonists and antagonists to the whole modify the vocal motor patterns generated, suggesting their important role in shaping the motor programs. 

 

Rhythmic neuronal activity is not limited to motor systems, but is prevalent across the entire CNS and is considered to underlie important functions such as perception, attention, and cognition.  Thus, understanding the biophysical principles that govern rhythm generation using a simple neural network has the potential to elucidate mechanisms underlying neuronal oscillations in general despite the anatomical and functional dissimilarities.

Through this project, training opportunities were provided for one postdoc, one graduate student, five research technicians, four undergraduate students, and one high school student, from a diverse background (seven out of 11 are female, three are an ethnic minority, and one is an LGBTQ student).  The postdoc was successful in obtaining a research position, two technicians went on to become graduate students (one additional technician is currently applying to graduate school), a graduate student finished his degree and is in the process of applying for a medical school, a high school student was accepted into an undergraduate institution of his choice, and all the other students remain in current institution to complete their degrees.  Thus, the training helped students to advance their career in science successfully. 

 

The results of the projects were presented at scientific meetingｓ, invited talks at other academic institutions, published or submitted for publication, or summarized as a senior thesis.  In addition, the results were disseminated to the general public through the PI and students’ appearance at local schools in Salt Lake City area, seminars for nonacademic employees at the University of Utah, and Brain Awareness Week.
